node.title: MPI_Init error on HPC
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am updating MOOSE on PSC, after install petsc, libmesh, and wasp, I build moose test and ./run_tests, get:
misc/check_error.function_conflict: Working Directory: /ocean/projects/mch230012p/yliup/projects/raccoon/moose/test/tests/misc/check_error
misc/check_error.function_conflict: Running command: /ocean/projects/mch230012p/yliup/projects/raccoon/moose/test/moose_test-opt -i function_conflict.i --error-override --no-gdb-backtrace
misc/check_error.function_conflict: [r001.ib.bridges2.psc.edu:04964] OPAL ERROR: Unreachable in file pmix3x_client.c at line 112
misc/check_error.function_conflict: --------------------------------------------------------------------------
misc/check_error.function_conflict: The application appears to have been direct launched using "srun",
misc/check_error.function_conflict: but OMPI was not built with SLURM's PMI support and therefore cannot
misc/check_error.function_conflict: execute. There are several options for building PMI support under
misc/check_error.function_conflict: SLURM, depending upon the SLURM version you are using:
misc/check_error.function_conflict: 
misc/check_error.function_conflict:   version 16.05 or later: you can use SLURM's PMIx support. This
misc/check_error.function_conflict:   requires that you configure and build SLURM --with-pmix.
misc/check_error.function_conflict: 
misc/check_error.function_conflict:   Versions earlier than 16.05: you must use either SLURM's PMI-1 or
misc/check_error.function_conflict:   PMI-2 support. SLURM builds PMI-1 by default, or you can manually
misc/check_error.function_conflict:   install PMI-2. You must then build Open MPI using --with-pmi pointing
misc/check_error.function_conflict:   to the SLURM PMI library location.
misc/check_error.function_conflict: 
misc/check_error.function_conflict: Please configure as appropriate and try again.
misc/check_error.function_conflict: --------------------------------------------------------------------------
misc/check_error.function_conflict: *** An error occurred in MPI_Init_thread
misc/check_error.function_conflict: *** on a NULL communicator
misc/check_error.function_conflict: *** MPI_ERRORS_ARE_FATAL (processes in this communicator will now abort,
misc/check_error.function_conflict: ***    and potentially your MPI job)
misc/check_error.function_conflict: [r001.ib.bridges2.psc.edu:04964] Local abort before MPI_INIT completed completed successfully, but am not able to aggregate error messages, and not able to guarantee that all other processes were killed!
misc/check_error.function_conflict: ################################################################################
misc/check_error.function_conflict: 
misc/check_error.function_conflict: Unable to match the following pattern against the program's output:
misc/check_error.function_conflict: 
misc/check_error.function_conflict: Function name 'x' could evaluate as a ParsedFunction
misc/check_error.function_conflict: 
misc/check_error.function_conflict: ################################################################################

misc/check_error.function_conflict: 
misc/check_error.function_conflict .......................................... FAILED (EXPECTED OUTPUT MISSING)

node.title: Problem of using MatchedValueBC
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
I would like to know if each variable must have one kernel at least. Can I just use the MatchedValueBC of this variable, but do not use kernel of this variable (that's to say the value of this variable equal to v  in MatchedValueBC in each linear and nonlinear iteration)?
Thanks!

Hello
Yes that's pretty much an obligation because having no kernels means huge rows of 0s in the Jacobian.
Just add a time derivative kernel on that variable, that does not change much
Guillaume
I have tried to add a ADTimeDerivative kernel, but the value equals to initial value and doesn't change. Is there any other kernel I can use?
why would it change? From the BC? The volume would stay constant for sure with just this kernel
Yes, the v in MatchedValueBC will change over the time.

and you want u to be equal to v everywhere in the domain?
or just on the boundary?
Just on the boundary.

and you are not seeing that happen? as if the BC is not being applied?
you could try this boundary condition too. v is a Functor (since it s a variable)
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/bcs/FunctorDirichletBC.html
OK, thanks a lot!

node.title: Auxkernels and AD
node.bodyText:
I have a compound auxvariable (mdot) that is the product of density, velocity and area. I use an aux instead of a material property due to a "product of averages is not equal to the average of the products" type of problem when variables are interpolated to QPs. I would like to use the AD system but it seems like auxkernels only return Real values. Is it possible for an auxvariable to be of type ADReal? I haven't found an example yet, so I am guessing not.
Thanks,
Joe Kelly

Hi Joe
No it's not possible for aux variables to be AD.
So you want to avoid evaluating the material property on the face by evaluating each component? You want to make sure face values are computed from the average of the values of that material property on the elements?
With Functor material properties we can define how the property gets evaluated for each argument (element, face, point, etc)
Guillaume

Thanks Guillaume. I'll take a look at functor properties.  I have only used them in an FVM context and this is FEM (1D).  After I read up on it, I'll either mark this as answered or have a better defined question. Below is an excerpt that explains the problem a bit better.
"To simplify the discussion, we’ll first consider a constant density case. It is essential to note that in this implementation the values of the flow area and the velocity variables only exist for the nodal points. Within a kernel, the values for the quadrature points are interpolated from the actual nodal values according to the type of quadrature being used. Again, to keep this simple, we’ll consider the most elementary type of quadrature: first-order Gauss. Thus, there is only one quadrature point located at the midpoint of the element and linear interpolation is used. Therefore,
A[0] = (1/2)(A0 + A1)
U[0] = (1/2) (U0 + U1)
Let’s consider the case where the flow area of an element doubles over its length and the velocity and area at the bottom of the element both have a value of unity. The corresponding volumetric flux would then have a value of 1 �m3/s�. For a constant density case, the volumetric flux at the top of the element would also have the same value. However, using the quadrature point values we would have
A[0] = (1/2)* (1+2) = 1.5
U[0]= (1/2)* (1+0.5)=0.75
so that the product U · A is equal to 1.125 rather than unity. Consequently, using the product of the quadrature values for velocity and flow area within the convective term can result in large mass errors rendering the calculation meaningless."

After looking at the functor material description, I don't believe that it solves the problem described above. Namely, for a 1D problem, only the velocity calculated at the nodal points is guaranteed to conserve the mass flow rate. If you interpolate each quantity (rho, velocity and area) to the QPs in forming a residual, that product does not equal the mass flow rate.

Well you're right that functor material properties were initially meant for facilitating on-the-fly evaluations and therefore meant it would be easy to combine functors / call them anywhere. So if mdot = rho v A then they allow to compute mdot(anywhere = x) as rho(x) * v(x) * A(x)
but it does not have to be that way. If I define a functor mdot that is equal to rho v A only on the nodes (definition of the functor for the NodalArg spatial argument), and equal to an interpolation of mdot between nodes elsewhere (definition of the functor for other spatial arguments, for example ElemQpArg, a Qp inside an element), then it does what you want.
You can look at ConstantFunctor in MooseFunctor.h for one of the simplest functor definitions.
Then PiecewiseByBlockLambdaFunctor in its own header for a more complex one.
My idea would be to create the one you need.
@lindsayad is the most knowledgeable on functors
Then for the user to create them, that will have to be done through a FunctorMaterial, which will create the functor as a functor material property.
Thanks Guillaume.  I think I understand and will give it a try.

sounds good. There is also a functor that leverages a map by faces. that can be an inspiration too. It's in Navier Stokes module
src/utils/FaceCenteredMapFunctor.C

There's a flaw in the thought process here. There is no interpolation in finite elements, just evaluation of the approximate solution. There is nothing special about the solution evaluation at the nodes vs. the interior of the elements. The evaluation of U at an interior element quadrature point is just as correct or incorrect as its evaluation at a node. Same with A. So you should not regard the product of U and A and rho at nodes as something special upon which you should base all other evaluations. If you have an issue with evaluation of mdot because of its composite nature, the fix would be to cast it as a degree of freedom in your system of equations, not try to project an auxiliary mdot into a finite element space

node.bodyText:
Dear Moose community,
I followed the coupled flow example under the folder of '(modules/combined/examples/geochem-porous_flow/geotes_weber_tensleep/porous_flow.i). The example uses '[PorousFlowFullySaturated]' action to save the mass fraction rate.

Considering the extension of multiple phases and unsaturated flow, my question is that can we use kernels such as, [PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative] to save the mass fraction rate?
Thanks for your time and help.
Robo

node.title: Unexpected Negative Temperatures in Cement Heat Transfer Simulation
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE Community,
I'm conducting a heat transfer simulation in cement and encountering an issue where the middle nodes of my domain exhibit negative temperatures. Below are the details of my setup:
Thermal Properties:
Thermal Conductivity: 2.6 W/m°C
Specific Heat: 790 J/kg°C
Density: 2500 kg/m³
Simulation Domain:
The domain consists of eight 2D triangular elements in a square configuration.
Boundary and Initial Conditions:
Initial Temperature: 0°C throughout the domain.
Bottom Boundary: Constant at 0°C.
Top Boundary: Linear increase from 0°C to 25°C over 10 seconds (0.25*t).
Despite these settings, I observed that the temperature at node 3 (located at x,y = (1,1)) drops to -8.92°C, which is unexpected. This issue does not occur when I run a similar simulation in ABAQUS.
Additionally, I attempted to use parameters from an official example, modifying them for my cement material:
Thermal Conductivity: Changed from 45.0 to 2.6 W/m°C
Specific Heat: Unsure if the original 0.5 is in kJ/kg°C.
I would appreciate any insights or suggestions on why these negative temperatures might be occurring and how to resolve this issue. Attached are the mesh file (I_mesh_example_square.e) and the input file (II_2_heat_conduction.i) for reference.
Thank you for your assistance!
My simple simulation:
heattests.zip
The MOOSE official example:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/combined/tutorials/introduction/thermomech_step01.html

Hello
You are very far from a steady state (the linear slope between the two boundaries one will expect) at this point.
The CFEM discretization in use can present oscillation in the presence of large perturbations, which imposing a dirichlet next to a volume far from that temperature is.
Do you know what discretization Abaqus uses?
Guillaume

Thank you very much for pointing me out!
I try to add temp from 0~25, and retain 25C to continue the simulation for an extra period
Furthermore, I use finer mesh than my example.
The results make sense to me now!!
And I do not really know what discretization Abaqus uses...
Will pay more attention on these aspects when doing the formal simulation by MOOSE.
But thanks again :)

    boundary = 'top bottom'
    variable = v
    momentum_component = 'y'
  []

  [outlet_p]
    type = INSFVOutletPressureBC
    boundary = 'right'
    variable = pressure
    function = 0.4
  []
[]

[FunctorMaterials]
  inactive = 'smooth'
  [jump]
    type = ADPiecewiseByBlockFunctorMaterial
    prop_name = 'porosity'
    subdomain_to_prop_value = '1 1
                               2 0.5'
  []
  [smooth]
    type = ADGenericFunctionFunctorMaterial
    prop_names = 'porosity'
    prop_values = 'smooth_jump'
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_shift_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu       NONZERO'
  line_search = 'none'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-10
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [inlet_p]
    type = SideAverageValue
    variable = 'pressure'
    boundary = 'left'
  []
  [outlet-u]
    type = SideIntegralVariablePostprocessor
    variable = u
    boundary = 'right'
  []
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
  csv = false
[]

Hello
You have too many objects called porosity. Rename one of them?
Maybe the auxiliary variable first?
Note that we have 3 different treatments implemented for porosity jump. Please try them and let us know your thoughts
Guillaume

Sounds good, is the issue that the example test was meant to show you can declare porosity either as an auxillary variable whose value is set by the IC or as a functor material? I am not sure why it had both to begin with.
Oh yeah sometimes tests are just doing whatever to get some lines of code tested

node.title: Time_scale in HPC Vs. Local system
node.bodyText:
Hello,
If I am running same input script on my local PC the 1st time step converges well at 1 sec, but if I am running the same script on HPC, my 1st time step converges at 6.25e-05. is there anything I need to add in the script that will show same time steps on HPC as on my local system?
Thank you

hello
Are you using the same number of cores on both systems?
Guillaume
no. On my local system I am using 4 cores on HPC I am using 400.

the preconditioning depends on the number of cores used.
We recommend 20k dofs per core as a guideline. 400 processes for an input that runs with 4 is likely overkill and detrimental to the runtime
In case of adaptivity how will we know the exact dof?

you can use a postprocessor to count the number of dofs
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/NumDOFs.html
uniform refinement generates 4x (in 2D) and 8x (in 3D) as many cells for the refined cells
